newsitem.title: MEXICO: Mexico peso closes firm on cautious long dlr sale.
newsitem.headline: Mexico peso closes firm on cautious long dlr sale.

text.p: Benchmark Mexican peso contracts closed firmer on Wednesday after dealers sold long dollar positions amid market caution ahead of key inflation data, traders said.
"The peso traded within a very narrow range, so there was not much to do. Some dealers are still long dollars, and that's why the peso firmed up," a trader said.
The benchmark 48-hour peso and its 24-hour stablemate closed 1.5 and 1.3 centavos firmer, respectively, at 7.8870/7.8890 and 7.8820/7.8850 per dollar.
Same-day peso contracts had earlier closed 0.6 of a centavo weaker at 7.8750/7.8850 per dollar.

"Many investors went long on dollars before the March 25 Federal Open Market Committee meeting to hedge against an agressive market reaction to U.S. interest rate hikes," a foreign exchange analyst said.
"But as the markets did not get out of hand, they have had to sell those positions little by little and that is why the peso has been trading firmly," he added.
Traders said market caution was due to inflation data expected shortly after the foreign exchange market closed.
"Dealers were very much looking forward to inflation data. We need to see the outcome to determine what we'll do tomorrow," another trader said.
A Reuters survey of Mexico City financial firms showed they expect an average increase of 1.31 percent in the March consumer price index, down from 1.68 percent in February.
Dealers said trading on Thursday would be greatly influenced by the inflation data, and said 48-hour peso contracts could weaken on pre-weekend swaps.

"The dollar is already very cheap for some and they may take that, or even reactions on the U.S. bond market ahead of Friday's U.S. data, as a pretext to weaken the peso on pre-weekend demand," a foreign exchange analyst said.
